section.title: Principles
section.para: Welcome to OmegaT, a computer-assisted translation (CAT) tool that offers great flexibility, performance and robustness, as well as features beyond those of commercial offerings, even for beginning translators.

listitem.para: An OmegaT translation project consists of a number of resources stored in separate folders, of a file that stores the location of all the resources and of a translation memory file that stores all the translations made while working on that project.
Translators can easily modify the contents or location of those resources at any time during the translation.

By default, resources include the project’s translation memory, which is automatically created upon project creation, and the files to translate. They can also include reference translation memories, glossaries, and other reference files.
Translators do not have to create a translation memory or associate one to a new project. OmegaT takes care of that automatically.
Translators can very easily reuse an existing projectʼs translation memory by simply adding new translation files to the old project, or by copying the old translation memory to a new project.

There is no limit to the number of translation memories that can be used as reference in a translation project, and OmegaT makes it very easy to assign different levels of priority to these additional memories.
Simple settings enable translators to easily share resources and work together on a project.

The team functionality offers industrial grade robustness and flexibility to synchronize project resources among team members, while allowing easy resolution of conflicts between different translations.
OmegaT is designed not only to facilitate the translation process, but also to ensure the translator does not have to worry about losing data.

note.para: You have not used OmegaT yet, but you remember the times you were translating in your word processor and a computer glitch wiped out the book translation you had been working on for the last six months, or the report that was due in one hour.
How can OmegaT help against such glitches?
Not to worry. The robust design of OmegaT makes it extremely unlikely that you have lost more than a few minutes of work.
Even if things look very broken, do not panic. Just follow the simple steps described in .

listitem.para: And before you ever need to follow those steps, OmegaT will allow you to focus on actually translating, and hopefully help you become a better translator.

section.title: Shortcuts
section.para: OmegaT looks a bit stern, if not outright unfriendly, to people who are used to button based interfaces. Buttons are very few in OmegaT. Most of the action takes place with the help of shortcuts associated to menu items.
Shortcuts are ubiquitous in this manual and you should be able very shortly to remember the few that are useful in the course of a standard translation day.

To avoid duplication of shortcut description, we have adopted the following notation in this manual: Single letters are used as a common identifier for modifiers.
In this manual: CE
On Windows and Linux: ControlE
On macOS: CommandE
See for details.

section.title: Manage your segments
section.para: The default setting for a translation project is to create sentences by splitting the paragraph blocks found in the document. See for details.
Segments that are within paragraph can be further segmented, or "unsegmented" (merged).
To further segment them, add a segmentation rule, to merge them, add an exception rule. See for details.

note.para:
Since a standard space character is often used as a boundary for a segment, if you want to merge two parts that are separated by a space character,

find the location of that space,
replace it by anything that is not a standard space but looks like a standard space, like a "non breakable space" for example,
save your modifications,

section.para: The pane is the place where you type your translation.

section.para: After you have typed the translation of a segment, use to move to the next untranslated segment.
Once you leave the segment, its translation is automatically stored into and will be used as reference for the rest of your translation.
See the menu for more navigation options.

note.para: OmegaT does not have different statuses for translated segments. Either a segment is translated, or it is not. If you need a separate review process, you can for example use the panes for problematic segments, or use to filter segments based on criteria that you set, and review only those, etc.

section.title: Manage your tags
section.para: If the documents you translate use bold, italics, or other decorative elements, OmegaT will convert them into tags that enclose the decorated text. Such files include LibreOffice files, HTML files, Microsoft Office files, etc. Documents will often also contain tags that have nothing to do with decorations, but are nevertheless important in the source files (and, consequently, in the translated files as well).
A source sentence might look like:

example.title: Sentence with decorative formatting
example.para: OmegaT is an easy-to-use program for eager translators

section.para: Depending on the original format, OmegaT, however, will present this sentence in a fashion similar to this one:

example.title: How decorations are displayed in OmegaT
example.para: OmegaT is an <t0/>easy to use<t1/> program for <t2/>eager<t3/> translators

section.para: The tags in OmegaT are grayed, making them easy to recognize. They are protected to prevent you from modifying their contents, but you can delete them, enter them by hand or move them around in the target sentence. See and for details.
You can define custom tags that will be managed in the same manner. See for details. You can also define strings that OmegaT should warn you about if you leave them in a translation. See for details.

If you make mistakes when you manage the tags, your translated files might fail to open. Use
to check your tags before you generate your translated files.

warning.para: If a file refuses to open in LibreOffice, Word or other application, it is often due to errors in the management of OmegaT tags. Return to OmegaT, check your document for tag issues and recreate the translated file.

section.title: Create the translated files
section.para: Whenever you want to see what your translation will look like in its final format, use .

warning.para: Any time you create the translated files, any previously created files with the same name will be overwritten. If you want to keep files from being overwritten, change their name after you created them, or automate the name modification with .
Your translations are always stored in , the project translation memory, located in the folder of your project.
Deleting the contents of the folder will never impact your translations.

section.para: The documents will be created in the folder of your project, and unless you have modified the names of the files that were previously created, they will be overwritten by the process...

Once the translated files have been created, you can open them in their original application to check their contents and eventually further modify them. Such external modifications will not be reflected in OmegaT.

Modifications made outside OmegaT can be reinserted in OmegaT (and thus in the project translation memory, to keep it up to date) either by entering them manually in the relevant segments, or by aligning the original file and the final translated file to create a new translation memory (TMX) file that will be put in the folder of your project folder. See for details.

section.title: Manage your projects

listitem.para: Translation projects are just folders containing files. You can create a new project for each new job, or you can add new source files to an existing project at any time.
You can access and modify the project settings with . To see the list of files in the project, use . You can access all the resource contents at any time with .
Every time you create the translated files (see , above), OmegaT creates three translation memories that contain the state of the translation of the files currently in the folder. See for details.

section.para: For a more comprehensive introduction see OmegaT for beginners on the OmegaT web site. If you need assistance with any aspect of OmegaT, feel free to join the OmegaT user groups.
